--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2012.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises a residential dwelling.ConsultationNo response received AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed extensions do not fully follow the guiding principles of the Council's Residentail design SPD. The proposed development is not considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design and would have an adverse impact on the character and appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.It is considered that the proposed dormers would not be a subordinate addition or of an archtectural style sypmapthetic to the host property. Cumulatively they would create visual clutter at roof level and it is considered the proposal would be an incongruous addition to the host property that would not site comfortably within the existing roof form or the built form of the host property overall. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to not be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than not in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way.  We have made available detailed advice in the form or our statutory policies in the Core Strategy, Supplementary Planning Documents, Planning Briefs and other informal written guidance, as well as offering a full pre-application advice service, in order to ensure that the applicant has been given every opportunity to submit an application which is likely to be considered favourably.

The development shall only be implemented in accordance with the details and measures approved as part of the air quality assessment. REASON: To ensure that the proposed development would not have an adverse impact, in terms of air pollution, and  in order to comply with the aims and objectives of Policy 5.2 of the London Plan and Policies CS1 and DM1 of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

These cover such works as  - the demolition of existing buildings, the erection of a new building or structure, the extension or alteration to a building, change of use of buildings, installation of services, underpinning works, and fire safety/means of escape works.  Notice of intention to demolish existing buildings must be given to the Council's Building Control Service at least 6 weeks before work starts.  A completed application form together with detailed plans must be submitted for approval before any building work is commenced.Party Wall ActThe Party Wall Act 1996 requires a building owner to notify, and obtain formal agreement from, any adjoining owner, where the building owner proposes to:- carry out work to an existing party wall;- build on the boundary with a neighbouring property;- in some circumstances, carry out groundworks within 6 metres of an adjoining building.Notification and agreements under this Act are the responsibility of the building owner and are quite separate from Building Regulations, or Planning Controls.  The Building Control Service will assume that an applicant has obtained any necessary agreements with the adjoining owner, and nothing said or implied by the Council should be taken as removing the necessity for the building owner to comply fully with the Party Wall Act. Further information and advice is to be found in "The Party Walls etc. Act 1996 - Explanatory Booklet".Property BoundariesYour attention is drawn to the fact that planning permission does not override property rights, and that if your proposal involves construction on or near the site boundary then you should take appropriate steps to ensure that you have correctly identified the position of the boundary, that you do not build over it, and that any works which affect a neighbours property in any way have the benefit of the appropriate agreement from that landowner. Failure to undertake the above steps may leave you liable to legal action by neighbouring landowners. If you require further information or advice, you should consult a solicitor.Consistency of PlansReasonable efforts have been made to check that the plans submitted for the purposes of this planning application are consistent from one to the next, and that the development hereby approved can be implemented in accordance with all of the plans submitted. Should it transpire that this is not possible and that your plans are flawed, please be clear that it may be impossible to implement this permission, and that any development undertaken which relies on this permission may be unauthorised and subject to enforcement action if expedient.Construction Site NoiseWhen undertaking demolition and/or noisy building work, please be considerate to your neighbours and do not undertake work before 8am or after 6pm Monday to Friday, before 8am or after 1pm on a Saturday or at any time on Sundays or Bank Holidays.  You are advised that the Council does have formal powers to control noise and nuisance under The Control of Pollution Act 1974, the Clean Air Acts and other relevant legislation, and that any works undertaken which impact unreasonably upon the surrounding area may be subject to action by the Council's Environmental Health Department.Definition of Approved in WritingWhere reference is made within the decision notice to a condition applying 'unless otherwise agreed in writing with the local planning authority', please be aware that only a formal application under section 73 or 96a of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (As Amended) is acceptable as a method of said written agreement.Ground Level / Base LevelUnless clearly specified otherwise, the base of the development shown on the approved plans is taken to be external ground level, and not a Damp Proof Course or Internal Finished Floor Level. The external ground level is expected to remain consistent before and after construction of the approved development unless specified otherwise on the approved plans.

The application seeks approval of the details required by Condition 5 (Fire safety) of planning permission 22/00296/HOU.The wording of Condition 5 (Fire safety) of planning permission 22/00296/HOU.Prior to beneficial occupation of the development to which this permission relates, Fire Safety information (a Strategy) shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority. The Strategy shall demonstrate how the development will achieve the highest standards of fire safety and shall include the following details:1) suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point;2) Appropriate fire alarm systems;3) Passive and active fire safety measures;4) appropriate construction details to minimise the risk of fire spread;5) provision of suitable and convenient means of escape/ an evacuation strategy;6) provision of suitable access and equipment for firefighting which is appropriate for the size and use of the development.The Strategy shall include a statement of competence. The development shall be carried out in accordance with the approved Strategy and thereafter maintained.Reason: In the interests of fire safety and to ensure the safety of all building users in accordance with Policy D12 (Fire safety) of the London Plan 2021.The applicant has deposited a fire strategy statement and Ground, First & Loft Floor Plan Fire Strategy Plan. It is consideredThe details have been reviewed  and officers are not satisfied that these meets the requirements for condition 5 of planning permission 22/00296/HOU. It is considered that the supporting information does not fully address all 6 criteria areas notably 1, 5 & 6. In addition the supporting fire safety strategy should specifically list out the 6 criteria and provide commentary on each point as to how the development will accord with each of the 6 criteria. It is acknowledged some of the information is there in the submission but for clarity it should be collated in the main strategy document and where additional documentation is provided this should be referenced and the reader signposted to the relevant supporting information.
Officer are not able to recommend that the details be approved that have been submitted in support of the requirements of condition 5 (fire strategy) of planning permission 23/00296/HOU

--- Officer Report ---IntroductionThis application is of a nature where the Council's Constitution delegates the authority to make the decision to Officers rather than it being decided by a Committee of Councillors.  Before preparing this summary report a Planning Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the relevant Development Plan policies and guidance, considered any relevant previous planning applications, and considered any comments made by those interested in the application such as consultees with specialist knowledge and nearby residents. By indicating that the development proposal complies with relevant Development Plan policies, the planning officer is taking into account the information submitted with the application, any previous relevant applications, any comments received in connection with the application and any other case specific considerations which are material to the decision.The Development Plan comprises:The London Plan 2021;RBK Core Strategy 2012;Kingston Town Centre Area Action Plan 2008; and,The South London Waste Plan 2022.This decision has been authorised by a Senior Officer (Authorising Officer) in the Development Management Service. Prior to endorsing the Planning Officer's recommendation, the Authorising Officer has familiarised themselves with the application site, the application documents, the relevant planning policies and guidance, any relevant history, and any representations received.Application SiteThe site comprises a residential dwelling.ConsultationNo response receivedRelevant History 23/00974/HOU - Erection of first floor side extension with alterations to the existing roof, and erection of rear dormer roof extension and installation of 3no. rooflights to the front roof slope to facilitate loft conversion - RefusedAssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.DesignWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS) (2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed scheme is a revision of planning application 23/00974/HOU. The proposal does not fully follow the guiding principles of the LPA's adopted Residential Design SPD. Whilst the scheme proposed has on the 1st floor side extension provided at least a 500mm set back from the front elevation and 500mm set down from the ridge the propoesed 1st floor extension would still extend across to the boundary.  As such officer's concerns still remain that the proposed extension at 1st floor would still not be a subordinate addition to the host property with its width extending to the side boundary still cause for concern. It is considered the proposal would unduly unbalance the pair of semi-detached properties which the host property forms part of and in turn would detract from the character and appearance of the host property, the pair of semi-detached properties the host property forms part of and the surrounding area. It is considered that the proposed 1st floor extension's proximity to the side boundary would create a dominant and overbearing addition to the host property despite the proposed set down from the ridge and set back from the front elevation. It is considered that the extension at 1st floor would still be visually intrusive in the streetscene and the private views of the site from the neighbouring properties eroding the spaciousness of the plot and still create an unnecessary sense of enclosure to the rear of the properties in particular 125 South Lane to the detriment of the existing living conditions of the neighbouring occupiers. Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment:  It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of loss of privacy. The application is supported by a daylight/sunlight survey. Whilst the survey concludes there would be some loss of light to the neighbouring occupiers the levels of light do not fall below what is considered acceptable by the BRE Guidance. As such it is considered that the applicant has demonstrated that the proposal would on balance not have an adverse impact on the neighbouring occupiers provision of daylight sunlight. It is considered that the proposal would create an unnecessary sense of enclosure and due to the orientation and proximity of the neighbouring properties in relation to the proposed extensions it is considered that this would also impact upon and reduce the outlook of neighbouring occupiers in particular 125 South Lane to the detriment of their existing living conditions.  ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to not be in accordance with the development plan and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than not in accordance with the development plan.Details of the Application SubmissionIn accordance with the requirements of Local Government Act 1972 details of the application submission were available on the Council's website during the assessment of the application.https://www.kingston.gov.uk/info/200155/planning_applications_and_permissions/263/find_a_planning_application_or_appeal--- Informatives ---Positive and ProactiveIn dealing with the application the Council has implemented the requirement in the National Planning Policy Framework to work with the applicant in a positive and proactive way. PREVIOUS RELEVANT HISTORY:Application reference 21/01375/FUL - Change of use from former hall to 4no. dwellinghouses with associated parking, amenity space, refuse/recycling facilities and landscaping. Granted planning permission, dated 23.09.2021.Application reference 22/01411/CLC - Details required for Conditions 3 (Materials), 4 (Construction Management Plan), 5 (Refuse), 6 (Boundaries), 7 (Levels), 11 (Sustainability), 14 (Cycle Parking) and 23 (Bat Survey) of planning permission 21/01375/FUL (Erection of 4no. dwellinghouses with associated parking, amenity space, refuse/recycling facilities and landscaping). Approved, dated 27.07.2022.Application reference 23/01449/CLC - Details required for Condition 8 (Landscaping Scheme), Condition 12 (Drainage System) and Condition 20 (Nature Conservation) of planning permission 21/01375/FUL (Erection of 4no. dwellinghouses with associated parking, amenity space, refuse/recycling facilities and landscaping). Refused, dated 25.07.2023.Application reference 23/02134/CLC - Details required for Condition 8 (landscaping scheme), 12 (drainage), and 20 (nature conservation) of 21/01375/FUL (Erection of 4no. dwellinghouses with associated parking, amenity space, refuse/recycling facilities and landscaping). Pending Consideration.CONSULTATIONS:23no. surrounding owner/occupiers were notified of the proposals. 1no. representation received, objecting to the proposals. Concerns summarised as follows:-	Potential for overlooking from proposed side windows.Officer's comment: Duly noted. The proposed side windows would be obscure glazed and non-openable below 1.7m, and so, therefore, would not introduce the opportunity for overlooking towards neighbouring properties. Please refer to main body for full assessment.SITE AND SURROUNDINGSThe site is located on the western side of Leatherhead Road. The site is a previously developed or brownfield parcel of land, which formerly accommodated a community hall structure (since largely demolished - some structures remain) and previously allotments (since disused). The land is currently overgrown and is not used for any purpose.Barwell Business Park is located on the opposite side of Leatherhead Road to the site, which comprises of a linear form of two-storey brick-built offices. The site is bounded to the rear by the open space of Sir Francis Baker Recreation Ground and Chessington Cricket Club. Four detached properties lie adjacent to the north fronting Leatherhead Road and two semi-detached chalet-style properties fronting Leatherhead Road lie adjacent to the south of the site, with those properties along Almshouse Lane backing onto the subject site.The site is located within designated Green Belt. The site does not contain any listed or locally listed buildings, nor is it located within a Conservation Area.The site has a Public Transport Accessibility Level (PTAL) rating of 2. The site lies within the Environment Agency's Flood Zone 1.PROPOSALApplication under Section 73 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 to carry out development without compliance with Condition 1 (Approved Plan) of Planning permission 21/01375/FUL (Erection of 4no. dwelling houses with associated parking, amenity space, refuse/recycling facilities and landscaping) to add new windows in the side elevation.ASSESSMENTThe main issues to consider when assessing this application relate to the principle of development, impact upon character and appearance and impact upon neighbouring residential amenity.Principle of DevelopmentThis application is made pursuant to Section 73 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended), which concerns applications to develop land without conditions previously attached. While this is, in effect, a fresh application for the entire development, the principle of the development has nevertheless already been established.On such an application, the local planning authority may only consider the conditions subject to which permission should be granted. It would therefore be unnecessary and unreasonable to revisit every issue which was relevant to the determination of the original application.In assessing the application, officers are mindful of any changes in planning policy or site circumstances since the grant of the original permission.It is acknowledged that there is no statutory definition of a minor material amendment (MMA) although the Planning Practice Guidance (PPG) explains that a MMA is 'likely to include any amendment where its scale and/or nature results in a development which is not substantially different from the one which has been approved'.Impact upon Character and Appearance of the Area Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposed changes submitted under this application to the approved permission comprise of the addition of windows to the side elevation. One additional obscure glazed and non-openable below 1.7m (above floor level) window is proposed to the first floor to the south flank elevation and one additional obscure glazed and non-openable below 1.7m (above floor level)  window is proposed to the ground floor on the north flank elevation. The windows would serve a first floor hallway and ground floor utility/wc. Officers consider that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the building and wider area. Impact upon Neighbouring Residential AmenityParagraph 130 of the NPPF 2021 states that planning decisions should ensure that developments will create places that are safe, inclusive and accessible and which promote health and well-being, with a high standard of amenity for existing and future users.Policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The proposed changes would not create any material loss of amenity or privacy beyond that assessed under the original application given that the windows would be obscure glazed and non-openable below 1.7m (above floor level). Overall, it is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties.Conclusion/Planning BalanceUnder the provisions of s.73 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990, the proposed amendments to Condition 1 (Approved Plans) of Planning Permission reference 21/01375/FUL are considered to maintain appropriate good quality design and would not result in material difference or material harm in terms of character and appearance of the proposed development, nor in terms of impacts upon neighbouring amenity. The proposals are considered to comply with Policy D3 of the London Plan, 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames LDF Core Strategy, April 2012.  RECOMMENDATIONGrant planning permission.
